VLIB_xyGradients_Magnitude_Orientations

Detailed Description


Functions

void VLIB_xyGradients_Magnitude_Orientations (const uint8_t img[restrict], uint16_t Width, uint16_t Height, uint8_t bins, uint32_t Mag[restrict], uint32_t Orien[restrict])

Function Documentation

void VLIB_xyGradients_Magnitude_Orientations ( const uint8_t  img[restrict],
uint16_t  Width,
uint16_t  Height,
uint8_t  bins,
uint32_t  Mag[restrict],
uint32_t  Orien[restrict] 
)

Description:
This function returns the magnitude of gradients and binned orientation of the gradients of an 8-bit input image. The number of orientations are programmable using the bins parameter. Gradient orientation values range from 0-180 and hence the maximum number of bins can be 180.
Method:
The image gradients are calculated with pixel subtraction and not by Sobel filter. The magnitude values returned are the sum of the absolute values of the x and y difference gradients. tan inverse of dy/dx gives the orientation direction. These orientations are mapped to one of the 0-(bins-1) bins. A pre computed look up table is built based on the number of bins. The computation cycle of this table depends on boundaries of the tan inverse values. The size of look-up table is 112kB. This gives the best through put of 1 cycle per pixel voting.
Parameters:
[in] img[] Input image array (UQ8.0)
[in] Width Input image width (UQ16.0)
[in] Height Inpuy image height (UQ16.0)
[in] bins Number of bins (UQ8.0)
[out] Mag[] Array for Magnitude (UQ32.0)
[out] Orien[] Array for Orientation (UQ32.0)
Assumptions:
  • The function processes only valid non-border pixels of the input correctly and this results in the outputs being cropped to have only (Width - 2) x (Height - 2) pixels total.
  • The first output pixel is obtained by processing the first valid non-border input pixel, causing a shift in the output gradient images with respect to the input image. The shift is one pixel to the left and one pixel to the top.
  • The output is cropped and does not contain border pixels. The output is written into the first (Width - 2) x (Height - 2) contiguous pixels.
